oblivion.translation[0].definitions[0].d: when something is completely forgotten or no longer important
oblivion.translation[0].definitions[0].e: The loserâ€™s name has been consigned to oblivion  (=completely forgotten).
Wind power presents too many advantages to be allowed to sink into oblivion.
oblivion.translation[0].definitions[1].d: the state of being unconscious or of not noticing what is happening
oblivion.translation[0].definitions[1].e: He had drunk himself into oblivion.
oblivion.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: Many political figures just fade into oblivion.
It was once a popular game, but it has since sunk into oblivion.
The old machines eventually slid into oblivion.
The achievements of these years should not be consigned to oblivion.
The charity has saved many fine old buildings from oblivion.
The party attracted little support and collapsed into political oblivion.
His first album led to instant oblivion.
be on the road to oblivion
Is this ancient tradition on the road to oblivion?
